prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: PG 1149-110
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: QSO sample log MBH = 7.92 log Lbol/LEdd = -0.97

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator setup: We observe the CO(2-1) line at 230.53800 GHz rest frame in Band 6. The requested bandwidth of 1875 MHz also covers the continuum and allows for redshift uncertainty in the catalog redshift, while the spectral resolution of 2 MHz is sufficient for the expected CO line width of several hundered km/s.
Angular resolution: We aim at spatially resolving the central sub-kpc region of the QSO host galaxies at z=0.05-0.076. A resolution of 0.2 arcsec corresponds to a physical resolution of 190-280 pc, sufficient to measure and map the gas density within the the central kpc.
Sensitivity: Observations of QSO host galaxies indicate total CO(1-0) luminosities of >10^8 K km/s pc^2 (Evans+01,06, Scoville+03). The conversion factor of L_CO(1-0) to L_CO(2-1) for QSOs is close to 1 (Carilli&Walter 2013). While we would expect that the bulk of the emission arises in the sub-kpc region, we conservatively attribute ~1/3 of L_CO to our region of interest. Thus, we aim at detecting CO in the central kpc at a luminosity of ~3*10^7 K km/s pc^2 at a signal-to-noise of 5sigma for our highest redshift target at z=0.076. This gives a sensitivity of 0.3mJy, which we use for the full QSO sample.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HE 0205-2408
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: QSO sample log MBH = 8.33 log Lbol/LEdd = -0.80

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator setup: We observe the CO(2-1) line at 230.53800 GHz rest frame in Band 6. The requested bandwidth of 1875 MHz also covers the continuum and allows for redshift uncertainty in the catalog redshift, while the spectral resolution of 2 MHz is sufficient for the expected CO line width of several hundered km/s.
Angular resolution: We aim at spatially resolving the central sub-kpc region of the QSO host galaxies at z=0.05-0.076. A resolution of 0.2 arcsec corresponds to a physical resolution of 190-280 pc, sufficient to measure and map the gas density within the the central kpc.
Sensitivity: Observations of QSO host galaxies indicate total CO(1-0) luminosities of >10^8 K km/s pc^2 (Evans+01,06, Scoville+03). The conversion factor of L_CO(1-0) to L_CO(2-1) for QSOs is close to 1 (Carilli&Walter 2013). While we would expect that the bulk of the emission arises in the sub-kpc region, we conservatively attribute ~1/3 of L_CO to our region of interest. Thus, we aim at detecting CO in the central kpc at a luminosity of ~3*10^7 K km/s pc^2 at a signal-to-noise of 5sigma for our highest redshift target at z=0.076. This gives a sensitivity of 0.3mJy, which we use for the full QSO sample.

Correlator setup: We observe the CO(2-1) line at 230.53800 GHz rest frame in Band 6. The requested bandwidth of 1875 MHz also covers the continuum and allows for redshift uncertainty in the catalog redshift, while the spectral resolution of 2 MHz is sufficient for the expected CO line width of several hundered km/s.
Angular resolution: For our comparison galaxies, we have to probe the same physical scales as for the QSO sample, i.e spatially resolving the central sub-kpc region. Since the inactive galaxies are at lower distances, with NGC 4697 the nearest at 12.5 Mpc, these correspond to a larger angular resolution. An angular resolution of 3 arcsec corresponds to a physical resolution of 180 pc for NGC 4697.
Sensitivity: While the galaxies are nearer by than the QSO sample, we need to be sensitive to lower gas densities and thus CO luminosities for these galaxies to test our scenario outlined in the science justification. We therefore propose to observe the galaxies at comparable sensitivity of 0.5mJy. This corresponds to a CO luminosity of several 10^4 K km/s pc^2, while total gas masses for normal galaxies are ~10^6-10^7 K km/s pc^2 (e.g. Fisher+13).

Correlator setup: We observe the CO(2-1) line at 230.53800 GHz rest frame in Band 6. The requested bandwidth of 1875 MHz also covers the continuum and allows for redshift uncertainty in the catalog redshift, while the spectral resolution of 2 MHz is sufficient for the expected CO line width of several hundered km/s.
Angular resolution: For our comparison galaxies, we have to probe the same physical scales as for the QSO sample, i.e spatially resolving the central sub-kpc region. Since the inactive galaxies are at lower distances (15-23 Mpc), these correspond to a larger angular resolution. An angular resolution of 2 arcsec corresponds to a physical resolution of 150-220 pc for our inactive galaxy sample.
Sensitivity: While the galaxies are nearer by than the QSO sample, we need to be sensitive to lower gas densities and thus CO luminosities for these galaxies to test our scenario outlined in the science justification. We therefore propose to observe the galaxies at comparable sensitivity of 0.5mJy. This corresponds to a CO luminosity of several 10^4 K km/s pc^2, while total gas masses for normal galaxies are ~10^6-10^7 K km/s pc^2 (e.g. Fisher+13).

Correlator setup: We observe the CO(2-1) line at 230.53800 GHz rest frame in Band 6. The requested bandwidth of 1875 MHz also covers the continuum and allows for redshift uncertainty in the catalog redshift, while the spectral resolution of 2 MHz is sufficient for the expected CO line width of several hundered km/s.

An angular resolution of 2 arcsec corresponds to a physical resolution of 150-220 pc for our inactive galaxy sample.

We therefore propose to observe the galaxies at comparable sensitivity of 0.5mJy. This corresponds to a CO luminosity of several 10^4 K km/s pc^2, while total gas masses for normal galaxies are ~10^6-10^7 K km/s pc^2 (e.g. Fisher+13).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: One of the key open questions in astrophysics is how supermassive black holes are fed. Large amounts of gas have to lose angular momentum and be channeled from several kiloparsec scales all the way down to the accretion disc. Recent simulations attribute a crucial role for the fueling of black holes to the gas density within the central sub-kiloparsec region. If the gas density there is sufficiently high, then a gaseous disk becomes gravitationally in-stable and can form a cascade of nested instabilities, which transport gas inward from several 100 parsec to sub-parsec scales. We propose to perform a simple but crucial test of this scenario. A clear prediction is that the host galaxies of strongly accreting AGN should have a systematically higher mean gas surface density compared to inactive galaxies with otherwise identical properties. With ALMA we are able to resolve the central sub-kiloparsec region and measure the molecular gas surface density in the host galaxies of strongly accreting AGN via the CO(2-1) line, which we will augment with equivalent observations for a comparison sample of inactive galaxies, with otherwise similar properties.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe, The University of Tokyo
